subject: boilerplate for testEquals, testCompareTo, testHashCode wanted
msgSnippet: Hi, Does anyone have any empirical boilerplate junit test methods that exercise the following commonly implemented/overridden methods of an arbitrary class?:
messageBody:
Hi,

Does anyone have any empirical boilerplate junit test methods that
exercise the following commonly implemented/overridden methods of an
arbitrary class?:
equals method
compareTo method (if class implements Comparable)
hashCode method

I understand that these methods must adhere to a standard contract
according to the java Lang Spec, and that it is easy for an
implementation of these to violate the contract in subtle ways - bugs
that result in hard to pin down behaviour. Rather than having to
dream up the tests for each class anew - I was hoping to 'reuse'
someone elses boilerplate code.... or receive suggestions about why
this a bad idea.

I believe that ideally these 'standard' tests would prove, (for any
object named x y and z):
equals():
1. x.equals(x) returns true
2. x.equals(y) returns true if y.equals(x)
3. if x.equals(y) is true and y.equals(z) is true then it follows
that x.equals(z) is also true
4. x.equals(y) returns consistent results over multiple invocations,
(if it's state is unchanged).
5. if x is not null, then x.equals(null) is false

compareTo() (implements Comparable):
1. the result of x.compareTo(y) has the opposite sign to
y.compareTo(x) (unless it's zero).
2. x.compareTo(y)>0 && y.compareTo(z)>0 implies x.compareTo(z)>0
3. (x.compareTo(y) == 0) is true if x.equals(y)

hashCode():
1. hashCode() must be overidden in this class if equals() is
2. multiple invocations on the same object return the same integer
(if it's state is unchanged)
3. if two objects return true to the equals method, then they both
return the same integer for a hashCode.
4. Unequals objects return different hashCodes - (I'm not sure that
this is a rule as such, just a good idea - should it be tested?)

I'd welcome comment on how to implement this in a generic fashion so
that junit tests can be worked up in seconds for any class.

Regards

Chris
